title.narrative: Emergency WASH provision for newly arrived IDPs in Kirkuk Governorate

description.narrative:
This project will provide continued support for Operation and Maintenance of WASH facilities and service provision in Laylan 3 IDP camp (known as Laylan C camp until April 2017) in Kirkuk Governorate where Tearfund has installed WASH facilities and has been supporting camp management in Operation and Maintenance since January 2017.
The project will cover meeting the emergency water, sanitation and hygiene needs of 12,500 individuals (2,500HH) through first line response activities in this priority displacement location. This involves overseeing and supporting the municipality in the operation of the boreholes serving the camp, and providing maintenance and repairs to water the distribution network. Tearfund will also focus on ensuring that households and communities have sufficient water storage solutions through providing maintenance and repairs to community water tanks, and providing household water storage containers (jerry cans, buckets, etc) to newly arriving IDPs. Tearfund will provide monitoring and support for the provision of sanitation services in Laylan 3 camp, providing management of municipality and camp workers in the maintenance and cleaning of latrines and bathing facilities, and providing emergency desludging, solid waste management/garbage collection and disposal.
The project will also contribute to increasing the practice of good hygiene behaviours, to reduce the risk of disease outbreak and focus on hygiene practices in basic conditions. This will be achieved via the provision of hygiene kits to new arrivals and monthly hygiene consumable items, including female and infant specific hygiene items. In addition, hygiene promotion activities will be carried out throughout the course of the project including household visits and beneficiary trainings.
Activities have been designed based on experience of providing operation and maintenance in the camp since January 2017, and in collaboration with the Kirkuk municipality and Kirkuk sub-national WASH cluster. This project is also designed in the anticipation of an influx of IDPs in the second half of 2017 into Kirkuk Governorate as a result of the expected operation to recover Hawiga from armed groups, which has the potential to cause significant levels of displacement.
